Thx, saved my life

Signed in just to say I really enjoyed this. This is something i can find myself listening to regularly, I don't really like taking the time to watch allchat, with this I can listen and play at the same time. Where can I make sure to hear more of these podcasts?{{champion:44}}
We're already working on a couple more! They'll show up on lol.com and the soundcloud just like this one, and we're also working on iTunes.

I listen to many podcasts and I love that Riot is doing one! However, I got really, really bored early on in the podcast because of the pointless talking. I don't know these guys, I don't want to hear about their personal lives, I don't want to hear them shoot the shit. I think that you guys need to work on getting the actual content there first, rather than straying and talking about everyday life topics. I think that this could be a great niche, but at the moment, with this content – I can't see myself listening to too many of these. I think it's ok to move into a personal realm once the audience knows you and respects your point of view and demeanor. Just my 2 cents =d

Anyway, high hopes for this! Pleeeeeeaseeee move away from personal content to actual league of legends topics.

Hey Stall!

I definitely understand your feelings about the personal content.

Right now, our plan is to have a good mix of personal and subject matter in the podcast. I feel that there's some intrinsic value in getting to know Rioters as people and gamers a bit more. We want to create some personal relationships with you guys, and a really effective way is to let you get to know us in new ways. 

I do apologize you didn't find it compelling and we'll be looking into adding annotation in future episodes so you can jump straight to the content you're looking for.

Thanks!

You guys should do a table of content thing for example in this Sourcefednerd video they talk about many different thing and a random guy in the comment just created a table of content.  It was very helpful because it help the viewer know where to find what they want to know and avoid stuff they don't want to know like spoilers or stuff they are not interested in.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HD5k2rp69s


The comment in question.
2:25 - Start
4:10 - iZombie/Gotham

31:56 - Agents of SHIELD
37:55 - Flash
41:39 - Arrow
48:27 - Sam Has A Point/Ant-Man Trailer/News & Rumors/Pull List
Great suggestion! We'll look into it.

I've been waiting for the update but I dread it at the same time. The simple, outdated and extremely powerful yordle is what I've fallen in love with. Please don't make her something she's not.{{champion:78}} Definitely excited though. It's been too long!

I completely understand, I'm this mix of "Please, please, please still be something like the Poppy I know and love." While also being extremely excited that she will finally get an update she needs. 

And while I think most, if not all, of her art needs an update I actually like her model. I may be the only person ever to say that lol.
If they change the lollipoppy art, there will be riots, as people can no longer engage in psychological warfare from the loading screen.

Regarding Taric:

I know that his lore is outdated as of the Great Retcon, and that his pizza-feet model needs to be redone, but why touch anything other than that? What design principle(s) does Taric's kit currently violate, and how exactly does it violate them?

As far as community opinions goes, why does it matter what the players who don't play Taric think about him? Players don't need to like every single champion. If you like him, play him; if not, there are another 120+ champs to chose from.

I am an avid Taric player, and I don't want to see my main changed needlessly. It's hard to stay loyal to a game when everything that you know and love about it is changing beneath your feet.

Taric's problem is that he comes from a time where Riot was less concerned about thematics, "player fantasy" and kit cohesion. His kit as it is now is functional, no doubt, but it's also not cohesive. Some parts of his kit say 'support', his heal, his armor aura, and his ult steroid for allies. 

But then if you look at these things, a lot of their power is tied up in things that aren't for a support, his heal is more effective when used soley on himself, his armor aura gives HIM bonus armor, of which only 12% goes to allies and it goes away when he uses its active which reduces an enemy's armor, his passive gives him damage base on his armor, his ult has more stats for him and only gives half to his allies. 

Further, his kit is all over the place, his armor reduction, ult, and passive seem to indicate an all in support but the only tool he has for that is his stun which doesn't even last that long even if you rank it up first. Meanwhile his heal and armor aura say safety/passive support but Taric doesn't scale well into the late game as a support mostly because, again, he has only one source of cc that is single target and doesn't last long.

Keep in mind, this is me looking at Taric as a support, if you were to take him solo lane top then he functions more as a tank that deals damage and can make up for falling behind with his utility and tankiness but I'm a support main so I can't really theorycraft on that use of him all that well.

The main problem he has is just, kit cohesion, what is it about Taric that makes people pick him over someone else? He needs a central theme to his kit for what he's supposed to do.

he is literally {{champion:3}} but with ad.

all ad comps meet a brick wall with him. and squishys arnt so squishy with him.
I think of him as a blue control deck in magic the gathering.

You pick Taric when you don't trust your adc's ability to play safe so you want someone who can keep him alive or go ham when your adc tries to go ham. At least that is why I play Taric, and he is my 2nd most played champ
That's why I pick Tahm. Oh you want to go in on the enemy while I can see that their jungler is coming? *NOM* Nope.

The thing that I love about Taric's kit is that he has a bit of everything! I don't see what's wrong with that. While Riot's current kit design philosophy might say that's bad because he doesn't have a strategic niche, I would say that the fact that he can do just about everything **is** unique--especially in light of Riot's recent trend of designing champions' kits as uber-specialized strategic caricatures.

As far as Shatter's bonus armor goes: activating shatter only gets rid of the flat armor bonus that he gives to himself, not the aura. Yes, reducing his armor reduces the strength of his aura, but only by 3-4 armor, even at max rank, which is a healthy type of tactical decision to incorporate into a kit.

Regarding the non-supportish elements of his kit, there's a reason that his secondary type is Fighter (NOT Tank). As long as he hasn't been starved of gold or experience, he has very good dueling power. That's simply a (vastly under-utilized) part of who he is.

While I would agree that his kit lacks mechanical cohesion, I think it has absolutely beautiful thematic cohesion as a gem-wielding paladin, and to me, that's what matters.

The thing with Taric, and keep in mind I am speaking as a Taric main here (well I have more games on naut but I am a Taric main at heart) Taric is like Viktor, he just does everything.  The difference here is that first of all, Vik does everything at about 70-90% efficiency, Taric on the other hand hovers from 30-60% efficiency.  On top of that the role of the sup should really be clear.  A mid who does everything works with most teamcomps, but a sup who does a bit of everything does nothing to help the teamcomp.  Taric is just too weak and too spread out in a position in which you really want a champ that does 1 or 2 things really well.  Just the 2 cents of a silver 3 player of course so take it with a grain of solo-queue players.... I mean salt

I play Viktor too (although I'm pretty bad with him), and I like your comparison between him and Taric as both being the "do everything"s of their roles. That being said, there are a couple of points in your comment that I disagree with.

First is the competence with which Taric does his little bit of everything. I interpret your statement to mean that he is underpowered (correct me if I'm wrong, but if so, please try to be a bit more precise in future comments). Taric has been hovering above a 50% win rate for a while now (and has just spiked up to fifth highest winrate in the game as of 5.22), so there's good empirical evidence that he's a viable champion.

Second is the point about him lacking a strategic niche. As I've said before, I don't see this as a bad thing. Plus, you literally can't get more universally helpful than by giving a 35 AD, AP, and Armor buff to your entire team--for any reasonable team comp, it's a guarantee that all three of those stats will be utilized to some degree. If anything, I'd say that it's mid-laner, not the support, who needs to be proficient at one or two specific things.

I have to disagree with a couple points you made.  First of all your last point. Supports almost always earn the least gold in the game.  They also have a couple items that they HAVE to build (Starting sup item, Sightstone, and boots before anything else)  This means that the vast majority of games supports only get to build 1-2 items to benefit the team.  These are usually things like Zekes, Frozen Heart, Locket, Banner, and Mikaels.  This means that a support has to focus on doing as much as possible at 1-2 things because they don't have the gold or inventory room to build to do damage and tank and weaken the enemy team.  A support has to buy items that match their scaling and boost what they already do to make an impact on the game.  A mid laner on the other hand can build to waveclear, poke, all in, and kite because they have more inventory room and all those items work together well.  Hence why Viktor is really powerful right now and why Taric is relatively unplayed.  

As for your point about Taric's win rate I have an example that fits this very well.  Skarner had both the 3rd highest win rate while being the 3rd least played champion in league at the same time for a while.  (Might be off by 1 or 2 places, my point still stands)  No one really played Skarner so a lot of players didn't know his exact CD's or by how much his q got reduced on autos.  However most of the people who did play Skarner didn't just play Skarner, for most of them Skarner was one of their top 3 played champions.  They knew the champ inside and out which is why he had an amazing win rate. It is the same with Heimer, most Heimer players are Heimer mains so Heim has a higher win rate than champions that everyone plays.  

I do agree to an extent with most of what you said in your 3rd paragraph though.  But I will go back to my point of supports not having many build options outside of their first 3 items.  The armor buff on Taric is pretty small until you at least have a frozen heart.  But unless they have a 4 AD team or 3 Ad and 2 weak AP then you really have to get a locket which only gives you more on your heal, not on your aura.  So the armor passive is no reason to pick him unless they are almost completely AD and your ult is super useful if you have a team with champs who like both AD and AP (Corki, Eve, Akali, etc)  Taric really is only an asset to his team if both team comps fit and he gets to his Frozen Heart.  Otherwise the only thing he has to offer is a buff that buffs himself more than others and a bunch of super long low impact CD's in the early game.  I still love him and put in plenty of games on him because I am so comfortable on him but I can completely understand why Riot feels the need to change him.  And don't tell me that they can just buff his numbers because then the Top lane unkillable Taric will just come back and go back to 1v4ing people with 0 skill required, it was a thing, and it isn't needed again.

1. Part of the miscommunication with the mids/supports subject may have been that we were both using the term "things" ambiguously. Regardless, the most important point in my third paragraph was that champions don't need specific niches in order to be viable or enjoyable,  but I didn't want to type the same thing over and over again without elaborating further, so I added the rest as basically a side-note.

2. So, you're addressing the validity of my conclusion that Taric's 52%(-55%) winrate is indicative that the champion is viable. But, despite my request, you didn't clarify whether the "30%-60%" line was an argument that Taric is not viable (and your other comments haven't been conclusive on this specific subject, either), so I'm still not sure if we're arguing over a non-issue here.

3. Why on earth would I "tell you that they can just buff his numbers"? He's overpowered as of 5.22. The fact that you perceive my opinion to be that Taric needs a buff, despite a dozen comments by me largely implying or outright stating the contrary, means that I'm either doing an extremely bad job of articulating my point, or you're doing a very poor job of comprehending it.

In light of the fact that these responses are getting longer and more tedious to write, and that they do not seem to be generating any sort of benefit for either of us, I suggest that we refrain from responding to each others' comments.

{{champion:44}}

i would argue that rather then trying to over complicate and make taric a harder champion to play he just needs a numbers rework with his ap ratio so that he does slightly more damage for those who decide to dip into that pool, obviously a visual update but other than that i think his kit works perfectly as a support. the beauty of his kit is that you have the ability to switch from pure defence to offence and in teamfights he is able to contribute a lot.

I've played him in jungle since S4 whenever Riot didn't make absurd jungle related decisions, and he's been amazing to me since, and one of my faves. One of the few reasons I even bother with this game, in fact.

In jungle you get all the farm you need so you can scale well, he brings a lot of dueling power to any lane he ganks, making him a good counter-ganker, or just pass by sustainer, being in jungle means he gets to meele more often and he is a good meta and comp based pick. I could 1v1 adcs or Yasuo and just come out on top unscathed, and he has amazing zoning or team backup, push for objectives and so on.

I would say I love him jungle exactly because he is so good at covering for flaws or tactical mistakes from your team mates, and he can be both passive or aggressive, and he's just a great pick for pubs.

Yes, his kit is actually built more for roaming or solo laning, or a passive playstyle bot requiring coordination, and so what? That means he already HAS his place in the meta, just not the one Riot wants to force feed to us.

He is a strong tank with good damage dealing nonetheless, but who's kit also backs up your team more directly than other tanks, and this overall DOES MAKE HIM UNIQUE! But he's unique in a natural way, not the artificial way Riot wants. He has a niche, but in a fun way, not the "meta" way Riot thinks it actually understands.

See, in other actually intelligent strategy games, it's actually a good, smart desgin to have a champ/deck/build/strategy that does a little bit of everything in a good order and timing, exactly because it matches the flow of the game...It's almost as if it's, dare I say, BALANCED?

No, the only real problem here is Riot's "disssign furrloserfy" for ~~games~~ spectacle sports...

I am also a taric player and I think that all he really needs are some visual updates and maybe new icons for his skills just because he needs some updates. I think if rito is gonna change something in his kit I think they shouldn't mess the fact that his kit is very simple and not very hard to play well. What makes Taric amazing is his ability to protect the adc in lane and can swing a teamfight in your favor with his amazing ultimate. Keeping your frontline healthy with your heal, your backline peeled with your stun and your team demolishing with your ultimate really makes him shine. Taric's kit isn't unfair or anti-fun its just not as complex or overloaded as the newer champions like kindred, azir, vel'koz or even tahm kench. If anything some nicer ratios would be nice and possibly a few changes to his e (Keep the point and click stun but some quality of life changes) and a slight buff to his w passive. Thats all from me thanks for someone else making a post that i could add on to about my opinions on taric.
Point-and-click stun. That's what he violates.

I don't get the thing about the point-and-click stun being unfair. Sure, it's not a skillshot, but it does require reflexes and an understanding of opportunity cost, and it does have counterplay.

Unless I'm mistaken, several assassins can get their full burst off in less than a second, which means that if you're sluggish with your stun, there are negative consequences. The fact that it's single-target and has a medium-long cooldown outside of an extended duel means that using it carelessly during a teamfight or an enemy gank makes your ADC vulnerable. The range is perfect. It's long-enough to prevent Taric from being hopelessly kiteable, and unlike Tahm Kench, he's not stuck on a 200-unit leash to his ADC. On the other hand, it's not long enough that he can stun targets that he's completely unable to chase down, and the fact that it's damage falls off with distance means that it can't be used as an obnoxious harass tool.

The ability also has a reasonable amount of counterplay. It can be countered by:

* champions with a spellshield
* champions who can block projectiles
* champions who can go untargetable
* items that block or remove CC
* champions who are invulnerable to CC


Altogether, that adds up to about ten champions and three items that have mechanics that can outright negate the ability. Plus, even if it can't be blocked or negated entirely, the duration can be reduced by the various sources of tenacity.

Also, as a side note, remember that there are some distinct disadvantages to point-and-click abilities--the primary one being that it can't hit targets that the user doesn't have vision of.

Maybe I didn't address your specific concern with the ability. If so, please let me know what it is.

I agree with you in most ways such as no one can argue he NEEDS a VU badly, but I think he could at least use some scaling changes. I feel like I fall behind other supports when I play Taric because he scales mostly with ap (and poorly at that), a little with BONUS hp, and a little with armor. I feel like its hard to itemize with him beyond the normal support items and buying armor. It just seems dumb to me that a champ like Taric scales with ap on 3/4 of his spells but has no room at all to build ap.

Keep in mind that, in terms of relative strength, you can't compare an AP scaling and an Armor scaling by percentage value alone. Ability power is not an inherently useful stat. AP-scaling abilities _give_ AP its usefulness, which inversely means that it would be a waste of gold on champions who do not scale with AP. Armor, on the other hand, does have inherent value, which means that it's useful even on champions who don't scale with armor. An AP-based 20% Spellblade passive is pretty meh, but an Armor-based 20% Spellblade passive is excellent, because despite the gold-per-point of the two stats being nearly equal, Armor also has inherent defensive value. So, I daresay that he scales primarily off of Armor, not AP. As for Taric not having room to build AP, I do think that it's viable to slip in a little bit of AP from items, but I may be in the minority on that.

"What design principle(s) does Taric's kit currently violate, and how exactly does it violate them?"

His Q isn't a skillshot :^)

We don't have to play as Taric, but we do have to play with him. It's pretty disappointing to get a Taric support. If you're already doing well by yourself, he's great. If you're counter-picked or just having a bad game, he's relatively useless. The same goes for playing against him. I can't tell you how many times I've been stunned by a Taric then proceeded to kill his ADC who tried to follow up on it. He doesn't have enough of an effect on the game.

As for the things people love about Taric, you can bet that those will stick around, he'll just do it in a different way that's more clear to the other players.

> If you're already doing well by yourself, he's great. If you're counter-picked or just having a bad game, he's relatively useless.

Isn't that how all champions are? From my experience with him, I'd say that he's less feast-or-famine than the majority of champions in the game.

> I can't tell you how many times I've been stunned by a Taric then proceeded to kill his ADC who tried to follow up on it.

Then the Taric or the other ADC is doing something wrong. Either the Taric player stunned his enemy's ADC when they were way out of range, he chose a poor time to initiate the trade, or his allied ADC is just plain bad at follow-up.

As for him not having an effect on the game... that's simply not true. He offers better 2v2 potential than any other support in the game. Mid- and late-game, he offers team-wide sustain and armor, as well as good protection for the ADC. Late-game, he turns into an unkillable raidboss, allowing him to take sustained damage from turrets and champions, giving him good backdooring and baiting. Furthermore, his ultimate has an extremely low cooldown and is excellent for taking objectives quickly.

> As for the things people love about Taric, you can bet that those will stick around, he'll just do it in a different way that's more clear to the other players.

What evidence do you have of this? Riot is very inconsistent when it comes to how well they preserve champion identities in their kit reworks. Plus, different players like different things about their champions, and I think that part of what makes Taric enjoyable is that he's so well-rounded, and not an extremely specialized champion that people only like because of one specific thing.

Everything you've said is very subjective, and yes everything I said is just as much so. However the fact that he was in the top three of champions that people want to see a rework on, points to the majority of players feeling like he's lacking.

Then the majority of players are just plain wrong, and Riot should not be pandering to a misconception, no matter how widely believed.

http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/taric
